marginalia.translation: The work entitled "Works and Days" shines forth; it is a work written by Hesiod on Economics and Husbandry to his brother Perses, which Virgil, in his work on husbandry, set forth to imitate himself. He nevertheless explained more widely the things he would embrace more shortly. For since altogether, taken before all other things, the 'rural works' consists of four books: ploughing, planting or grafting, 'gardening' in Greek ; the grazing of the greater and lesser cattle (horses, oxes, sheep, goats) and the making of honey. Virgil pursues these singular things in his singular book methodically enough And in the same place, Xenophon's 'Oeconomicus' looks closely, as if the singular discourse useful for economics. Since the collaction of these things by Tusser, it will be neither unuseful for the economic, nor unpleasant for the philosopher.
